titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Went up again this morning to the Adelphi. Visit in form to Mr and Mrs: King, Mr: and Mrs: Gore, and Mr: & Mrs: Pinkney. The last of them only at home.— Writing Letters to my friends in America.
2. Continued writing, and spend all my time between the Adelphi and Mr: Johnson’s. Mrs: Court and her daughters dined there this day.— Mr Calhoun in the Evening.
3. Passed the whole forenoon in writing. Dined with all the family at Mr: Hewlett’s. Mrs: Court and her daughters were there. Returned between 9 and 10 at night.

4. Passed the forenoon at the Adelphi. Dined with the family and an American party at Mr: King’s.— Wrote a Letter to Mr: Murray. Mr: King shewed me a letter which he has written, and proposes to send to Mr: Talleyrand, now the french Minister of foreign affairs.
5. Came up to the Adelphi this morning. With Mr: Hall, paid a visit to Mr: Tudor, and Mr: Foster.— Dined at Mr: Copley’s. Mr: Trumbull, Mr Erving & Mr: Heaviside. Home between 9 and 10.

6. Mrs: Adams unwell, and could not go to Church. Went with the rest of the Ladies to the foundling, and heard Mr: Hewlett again. After which he accompanied us with one of the Governors over the buildings. Saw the boys and the girls at dinner in separate halls, about seventy of each sex. Their dinner consisted of baked beef and string beans, apparently excellent & in abundance. They were well clothed, and appeared very healthy. The institution provides for 360 children. We saw the kitchens likewise which were very neat, and where they cook with very little fuel, upon the plan proposed by Count Rumford.— The portrait of the founder Captain Coram by Hogarth, and the original picture of the March to Finchley are there, and were given by Hogarth.— Met there Mr: Boylston and George Apthorp with his wife whom he has just married, and to whom he introduced me.— We called at Mr: Pinkney’s, but they were not at home. After returning, attempted to take a walk, and were caught in the rain. The two Mr: Hall’s dined and passed the Evening at Mr: Johnson’s. Mrs: Johnson very unwell in the Evening and retired. We had some music. Letter from S. C. Blyth, which I answered.

7. Went with Mr: Johnson this morning, to look up a traveling carriage. Found one, which I believe must answer my purpose. Forenoon at the Adelphi, writing Letters. Dined with the family at Mr: Pinkney’s, company in general the same as at Mr: King’s two days ago. Mr: Pinkney is fond of Poetry.— Conversation with Mr: King. His letters from America, not exactly such as he could wish.

8. Walk up to the Went to pay a visit to Dr: Bancroft, and to Mr: King. found the latter at home, and had a long conversation with him upon our public affairs.— I perceive something of the talents which have raised him so rapidly to his present situation.— His career has been brilliant and will I think continue to be so.— Walked back.— Mr: Claggett dined with us. Mrs: Adams very unwell the afternoon & evening.

9. Passed the forenoon at the Adelphi. Mrs: Adams again somewhat unwell. We dined however, and passed the principal part of the Evening at Mrs: Court’s. Mr: Hewlett there. He rode home with us, and told me on the road several anecdotes of Sheridan & Dr: Wolcott.

10. Morning at the Adelphi. Dined at home. Mr: Murdoch passed the Evening there. He has just returned from France.— I make out to write a little but not much. Called on Mr: Tudor to deliver him a little package, for my brother-in-Law T. B. Johnson. Left it at Mr Tudor’s lodgings not finding him at home.

11. Called on both Mr: Hall’s this morning as I came up in town. Fitch Hall, ill with a rhumatism. J. Hall went with me and dined at Mr: Johnson’s. We went in the Evening to the Haymarket Theatre, where we saw, Quarter of an Hour before dinner—with a new Play of Colman’s called the Heir at Law, and the Mock Doctor.— The last is a very miserable thing as thus written & performed.— They kept us till after twelve. Mr: Murdoch & my brother joined us there.— We came away without them. House very much crowded and warm.

12. Morning at the Adelphi— Dined at Mr: Gore’s with a large company. Dinner of ceremony. Mr: & Mrs: Ansty, and Mrs: Jeffrey besides the company at Mr: King’s & Mr: Pinkney’s. As we returned home, we saw some thin and scattered illuminations on account of the Prince of Wales’s birth-day. A gloomy light serving only to shew darkness visible.

13. We went to Church this morning at the foundling.— Mr: Hewletts sermon a good one: upon slander and Detraction.— Rode afterwards round the Park.— Called as we went home upon Mr: Brooks, who is yet ill, though better than when I saw him last.— My brother came to dinner Mr: Murdoch engaged. Mr: J. Hall detained by the illness of Fitch, who took by mistake this morning a large dose of laudanum. We are anxious for him.— Mr: & Mrs: Pinkney passed part of the Evening, and Mr: Murdoch.— Mrs: Pinkney says she loves dearly all the public places. Means to go three times a week to the Play, next Winter.— Poor thing!
14. Went up to the Adelphi, and wrote a little—very little.— Called on Mr: Hall; who is better this morning. Met there Mr: Rogers & Mr: Bell.— Reading in the Evening.

15. Visit this morning from Mr: Maitland.— Went to the Adelphi. Met Hall, as I was going. sat chatting with him till 4 o’clock. Returned home with Mrs: Johnson. Unwell in the Evening. Mr: Murdoch, to pass it.
16. Arrival of the West India fleet N.B.— Quite unwell— Walk up to the Adelphi.— Called on Mr: Spooner. Angel Court. Throgmorton Street.— Wrote a short letter to Mr: Murray.

17. Still unwell.— Called at Mr: Kings. He shewed me several Letters from Genl: Pinckney to the Secretary of State.— To the Adelphi.— Met Hall & walked with him. called at the Shakespear Gallery and looked at an Original Picture of Milton, from which a print has just been published. Find myself better this day, towards night.

18. Walk to the Adelphi and returned early.— Dined at Mr: Murdoch’s.— A Mr: Beale in company, who made himself ridiculous.— Murdoch persuaded him to withdraw. Conversation with Mr: Gilpin,Mr: Pinckney &c— Found Mrs: Hewlett upon our return home.

19. Rainy night and morning. Walk to the Adelphi, where I found Messrs: Hall, Rogers & Bell. Soon returned home to dinner, where we met Mrs: Court. This course of life has too much of luxury and of indolence for me.— It is not however to last long.

20. Went to Church this morning at the foundling.— Mr: Hewlett preached a good sermon— Singing very good.— Reading Milton after returning from Church. J. Hall, and my brother at dinner, & also Mr: Murdoch in the Evening.

21. Came up to the Adelphi, and wrote in the morning. I cannot find so much time for thinking as I wish.— Returned to dinner.— Mrs: Court there; and the Evening. A little music.— We have not the art of employing every moment of time—therefore not that of perpetual amusement.

bibl.author: JQA
bibl.subject: Courtship and Marriage of JQA and LCA

div.p: 22. Called upon J. Hall. Walked with him and looked over some bookstalls: made a few purchases: but books at their best rate are costly in this Country.— Home to dinner, and in the Evening went to a ball, given by Mr: Murdoch; on the occasion of Mrs: Adams’s marriage. Mr: & Mrs: King, Mr: & Mrs Pinkney, Madame Letourneur & her daughter, were of the company. The evening very pleasant.— We broke up between 1 and 2 in the morning.

23. Somewhat fatigued. Walked up however to the Adelphi. Visit to Mr: J. Taylor.— At the Shakespeare Gallery. Purchased a print just published, from an original Portrait of Milton, by Plas. It belongs to Capel Lofft, but I think differs considerably from the common pictures of the british Homer.— Mr: Murdoch & Mr: Calhoun to pass the Evening. Still in company, and still without employment.

24. Reading light poetry. Might employ my time to advantage. But there is perhaps a disposition for any species of application in preference to that which may be turn’d to some use. Walked to and from the Adelphi.— Purchasing Cooke’s beautiful editions of Poets— Took the Milton.— Pass perhaps too great a portion of time in reading him: at least it rendered this Evening short and pleasant.

25. Dined at the Adelphi. Mr: J. Hall with us. Visit to Mr: Marshall, & to Mr: D’Asp. neither at home. Ball in the Evening at Mr: Johnson’s.— Letters and Papers from America. The situation of affairs there very indifferent— I should feel it more, had I expected it less.— Our company was numerous, and we did not break up till nearly 4. in the morning.
26. Pass’d the day as usual after a party like that of yesterday. At the Adelphi however. Evening dull, all of us being much fatigued. I am even scarcely capable of thinking.

27. Went to St: Paul’s Church just after 11. the hour for beginning church in general: but found the service there nearly over: it begins 1/4 before 10. Went to the Adelphi. Read the last book of the Paradise lost. Returned to St: Church Paul’s at 3. and heard the afternoon service. The singing very good. The sermon good. Dined late. Went to Mr: King’s between 7. & 8. pass’d a couple of hours there. Found Mr: Murdoch upon our return & were up again till 1.
28. Spent the day between Cooper’s Row and the Adelphi, as usual.— Mr: Johnson unwell Read in the Evening. Southey’s Letters from Spain and Portugal.— Weather warm.
29. Passed an hour or two at the Adelphi writing. Packing up at Mr: Johnson’s, and making preparations for their departure for America.— Mr: Murdoch to pass the Evening. Family unwell.

30. Called this morning upon Mr: King. He lent me some American Newspapers, and a pamphlet. Walked from thence to Mr: Johnson’s. Mrs: Court in the Evening, & Mr: Murdoch the former at dinner also.— Mr: Johnson ill.— The cause, an unhappy one.

31. Determined at length to return on Saturday to my lodgings at the Adelphi, and take Mrs: Adams. Carried up my things. Dined at Mr: d’Asp’s the Swedish Minister, an old acquaintance of mine. Met there Mr: King, The Baron Oxenstierna, Swedish Minister at Lisbon, now absent with permission, and several other Gentlemen. Found Mrs: Court, Mr Brookes & the Hall’s, upon my return. The situation has become very painful.

Day, for this month only. Rise at about 9. Breakfast with the family at ten. Read till about 1. Walk or ride to the Adelphi, or pay a visit or two.— Write or idle time, chiefly the latter till half after 4. Walk down to Mr: Johnson’s. dine at about 6, and pass the evening till 10 with the family. Sup, and bed at midnight or later.
